    Data Science Learning Progressions
    .
    ğŸ”—

    ğŸ”—

    Section 2.1 Building Data Curiosity and Questioning Skills

    Data science begins with curiosityâ€”wondering about the world and asking questions that can be explored through information. But not all questions are â€œdata questions.â€ Letâ€™s explore what makes a good question for data investigation and how to help students develop this skill.
    ğŸ”—

    Checkpoint 2.1.1.

    A student asks, â€œWhatâ€™s the best color?â€ Why wouldnâ€™t this make a good data investigation question?
    ğŸ”—
    Hint.
    Think about whether this question can be answered objectively through collecting information.
    ğŸ”—
    ğŸ”—
    Answer.
    This is purely opinion-based with no objective answer that data could reveal.
    ğŸ”—
    ğŸ”—
    Solution.
    While you could survey people about color preferences, thereâ€™s no objective â€œbestâ€ color to discover through data.     ğŸ”—
    ğŸ”—
    ğŸ”—

    ğŸ”—

    The Strategy: Whenever you present any information to students (a graph, a historical fact, a scientific observation), pause and ask: â€œWhat do you notice?â€ and â€œWhat do you wonder?â€

    Section 2.2 Recognizing Bias and Developing Ethical Data Thinking

    One of the most important data dispositions is healthy skepticism. Not all data tells the complete story, and students need to develop the habit of asking: â€œWhat might this data be missing? Who collected this and why?â€ Additionally, when we collect information about people, we have responsibilities.
    ğŸ”—
    This 5-minute video explains bias in data collection in kid-friendly terms.
    ğŸ”—
    Letâ€™s explore bias through a simple scenario that works for any age:
    ğŸ”—

    Exploration 2.2.1. The Playground Survey Problem.

    The Scenario: Jamie wants to find out what the most popular playground activity is at their school. They survey 20 students during recess and find that 15 out of 20 say â€œbasketballâ€ is their favorite.
    ğŸ”—
    Jamieâ€™s conclusion: â€œBasketball is definitely the most popular playground activity at our school!â€
    ğŸ”—
    What questions should we ask about this conclusion? Where did Jamie conduct the survey? When did they survey? Who did they ask? How did they ask the question? What other information might be helpful?
    ğŸ”—
    ğŸ”—

    Checkpoint 2.2.1.

    In the playground survey scenario, what would likely be the MOST significant source of bias?
    ğŸ”—
    Hint.
    Think about how the location of data collection might influence the responses.
    ğŸ”—
    ğŸ”—
    Answer.
    Jamie probably surveyed students near the basketball court, creating location bias.
    ğŸ”—
    ğŸ”—
    Solution.
    Location bias is the biggest issue here. If Jamie surveyed students who were playing basketball or near the basketball court, those students would be much more likely to say basketball is their favorite activity. This shows how WHERE we collect data can significantly influence the results, even with good intentions.
    ğŸ”—
    ğŸ”—
    ğŸ”—

    Checkpoint 2.2.2.

    How could Jamie improve their survey to get more reliable results?
    ğŸ”—
    Hint.
    Consider ways to make sure all students have an equal chance to participate.
    ğŸ”—
    ğŸ”—
    Answer.
    Randomly select students from class lists to survey, rather than surveying based on location.
    ğŸ”—
    ğŸ”—
    Solution.
    Random selection from class lists would give every student an equal chance to participate, regardless of which playground activity they prefer. Jamie could also survey at different times and locations, but random selection is the most systematic approach to reducing bias.
    ğŸ”—
    ğŸ”—
    ğŸ”—

    Exploration 2.2.2. Try This Week: Bias Detectives.

    Time needed: 15 minutes
    ğŸ”—
    Materials: A simple chart, graph, or claim from your curriculum
    ğŸ”—
    The Activity: Present any data visualization or claim to your students. Ask them to put on their â€œdetective hatsâ€ and investigate using age-appropriate questions.

    Section 3.3 Organizing and Cleaning Data: From Messy to Meaningful

    Students have collected data about their favorite lunch foods and created a simple bar graph. Whatâ€™s the most important question to ask them first?

    ğŸ”—
    ğŸ”—

    ğŸ”—
    ğŸ”—

    Exploration 4.1.1. Try This Week: Pattern Hunting.

    How it works: Use this progression with any data your students have collected or are studying:
    ğŸ”—

    2. Compare: â€œWhatâ€™s the same? Whatâ€™s different? Whatâ€™s surprising?â€
    ğŸ”—

    ğŸ”—
    ğŸ”—

    ğŸ”—
    ğŸ”—

    ğŸ”—
    â€¢ Start with â€œWhatâ€™s typical?â€ or â€œWhatâ€™s most common?â€

    â€¢ Use concrete language: â€œMost students chose...â€ or â€œAbout half the class...â€
    ğŸ”—
    â€¢ Compare groups: â€œBoys tend to..., while girls tend to...â€
    ğŸ”—

    ğŸ”—
    â€¢ Calculate and compare mean, median, and mode when appropriate

    â€¢ Discuss range and what it tells us about variability

    ğŸ”—

    ğŸ”—

    Section 5.1 Drawing Conclusions and Making Evidence-Based Claims

    The ability to look at data and draw reasonable conclusions is fundamental to scientific thinking. Students need to learn how to move from â€œHereâ€™s what we foundâ€ to â€œHereâ€™s what this meansâ€ while being appropriately confident about their claims.
    ğŸ”—

    Checkpoint 5.1.1.

    Students survey 25 classmates about study habits and find that students who study with music report spending more time studying. A student concludes: â€œMusic makes people study longer.â€ Whatâ€™s problematic about this conclusion?
    ğŸ”—
    Hint.
    Think about the difference between describing a pattern and explaining why it exists.
    ğŸ”—
    ğŸ”—
    Answer.
    It assumes causation from correlation and goes beyond what the data can support.
    ğŸ”—
    ğŸ”—
    Solution.
    The data shows a relationship but doesnâ€™t prove causation. Students who study with music might study longer for other reasons (they enjoy studying more, they have different study habits, theyâ€™re more motivated), or students who plan to study longer might choose to use music.     ğŸ”—
    ğŸ”—
    ğŸ”—

    The Framework: Teach students to structure claims using this progression:
    ğŸ”—
    1. What we found: â€œOur data shows that...â€

    ğŸ”—

    Section 5.2 Understanding Uncertainty and Limitations

    Exploration 5.2.1. Try This Week: Limitations Detective.

    ğŸ”—
    The Process: After students have drawn conclusions from data, have them systematically consider limitations:
    ğŸ”—
    Sample Limitations: Who did we ask? Who didnâ€™t we ask? Does our sample represent everyone we want to know about?
    ğŸ”—

    ğŸ”—

    ğŸ”—
    Elementary Application: After surveying favorite pizza toppings: â€œWe only asked kids in our class, so this might not be true for other classes. We also only gave three choices, so we donâ€™t know about other toppings people might like.â€
    ğŸ”—

    Section 5.3 Avoiding Common Interpretation Pitfalls

    There are predictable mistakes that people make when interpreting data. Teaching students to recognize and avoid these pitfalls helps them become more sophisticated consumers and creators of data-based arguments.

    Checkpoint 5.3.1.

    Students find that overall, boys in their school have higher math test scores than girls. However, when they look at each grade level separately, girls have higher scores in every single grade. How is this possible?
    ğŸ”—
    Hint.
    Think about how the composition of the groups might affect overall averages.
    ğŸ”—
    ğŸ”—
    Answer.
    This could happen if there are more boys in higher grades (where all students score higher) and more girls in lower grades.
    ğŸ”—
    ğŸ”—
    Solution.
    This is an example of Simpsonâ€™s Paradoxâ€”when overall trends reverse when you look at subgroups.     ğŸ”—
    ğŸ”—

    ğŸ”—

    ğŸ”—
    ğŸ”—
    Solution.
    This is cherry-pickingâ€”selecting only data that supports your preferred conclusion.     Checkpoint 5.3.3.

    Exploration 5.3.2. Common Interpretation Pitfalls and Prevention Strategies.

    Pitfall 1: Assuming causation from correlation
    ğŸ”—
    Prevention: Always ask â€œWhat else could explain this relationship?â€
    ğŸ”—
    Pitfall 2: Overgeneralizing from limited samples
    ğŸ”—
    Prevention: Be specific about who your data represents
    ğŸ”—
    Pitfall 3: Ignoring missing data or excluded groups
    ğŸ”—
    Prevention: Ask â€œWho is not represented in this data?â€
    ğŸ”—
    Pitfall 4: Cherry-picking supportive evidence
    ğŸ”—
    Prevention: Look for patterns across multiple sources
    ğŸ”—
    Pitfall 5: Treating all data as equally reliable
    ğŸ”—
    Prevention: Consider data quality, source, and methods

    ğŸ”—

    Checkpoint 6.1.1.

    ğŸ”—

    ğŸ”—
    ğŸ”—

    ğŸ”—
    ğŸ”—
    Solution.

    ğŸ”—
    ğŸ”—

    ğŸ”—

    ğŸ”—
    4. Honest Representation: Does the visual accurately represent the data without misleading?
    ğŸ”—
    Elementary Example: Start with a basic bar graph of favorite colors. Improve by adding a clear title (â€œOur Classâ€™s Favorite Colorsâ€), labeling axes (â€œColorsâ€ and â€œNumber of Studentsâ€), using distinct colors, and making bars proportional to the data.

    Section 7.1 The Data Science Lesson Design Framework

    ğŸ”—

    ğŸ”—

    ğŸ”—

    ğŸ”—

    ğŸ”—
    4. Active Investigation: How will students work with data to explore the question? What will they do, not just learn about?
    ğŸ”—
    5. Reflection and Extension: How will students make sense of what they learned? What questions does this raise for future investigation?
    ğŸ”—
    ğŸ”—

    Section 7.3 Avoiding Common Pitfalls

    There are predictable challenges that new data science educators encounter. Learning to recognize and plan for these pitfalls will help your first lesson go smoothly and build your confidence for future lessons.
    ğŸ”—

    Exploration 7.3.1. The Most Common Pitfalls and How to Avoid Them.

    Pitfall 1: Trying to Cover Too Much
    ğŸ”—
    Problem: Planning lessons that touch on all five strands superficially
    ğŸ”—
    Solution: Choose 1-2 strands to emphasize deeply. Better to do one thing well than five things poorly.
    ğŸ”—
    Pitfall 2: Technology Taking Over
    ğŸ”—
    Problem: Spending more time troubleshooting tools than thinking about data
    ğŸ”—
    Solution: Use simple, reliable tools youâ€™re comfortable with. Paper and pencil work fine for first lessons!
    ğŸ”—
    Pitfall 3: Weak Curriculum Connections
    ğŸ”—
    Problem: Data science activities that feel like add-ons rather than integral parts of learning
    ğŸ”—
    Solution: Start with curriculum content, then find the data angle. Not the other way around.
    ğŸ”—
    Pitfall 4: Questions Without Answers
    ğŸ”—
    Problem: Investigation questions that are too broad, too complex, or impossible to answer with available data
    ğŸ”—
    Solution: Test your question yourself first. Can you actually answer it with the data and methods youâ€™re planning?
    ğŸ”—
    Pitfall 5: No Plan for Extensions
    ğŸ”—
    Problem: Students finish early or want to investigate further, but thereâ€™s no plan for what to do next
    ğŸ”—
    Solution: Always have 2-3 follow-up questions ready for students who want to dig deeper.
    ğŸ”—
    ğŸ”—

    Checkpoint 7.3.1.

    Looking at your lesson plan so far, which pitfall are you most at risk of falling into?

    ğŸ”—
    ğŸ”—

    ğŸ”—
    ğŸ”—
    Solution.

    ğŸ”—
    ğŸ”—

    Exploration 7.3.2. Building in Flexibility and Backup Plans.

    Data science lessons often take unexpected turns because students get curious and want to explore further. This is good! But it requires planning for flexibility.
    ğŸ”—

    ğŸ”—

    ğŸ”—

    ğŸ”—
    Extension Questions: Have 2-3 follow-up questions ready for fast finishers or naturally emerging curiosity
    ğŸ”—
    Simplification Options: Know how to simplify your investigation if students are struggling or time is short
    ğŸ”—
    Low-Tech Alternatives: Have non-digital backup plans in case technology fails
    ğŸ”—
    ğŸ”—

    Section 9.1 What Does Data Science Learning Look Like?

    Data science learning is often more visible in how students think and approach problems than in what they produce. Recognizing these thinking patterns helps you support student growth and assess their development across the five data science strands.
    ğŸ”—

    Exploration 9.1.1. Observable Signs of Data Science Thinking.

    Data Dispositions and Responsibilities (Strand A):
    ğŸ”—
    â€¢ Students ask â€œHow do we know that?â€ or â€œWhere did this data come from?â€
    ğŸ”—
    â€¢ They question claims that arenâ€™t supported by evidence
    ğŸ”—
    â€¢ Students consider who might be missing from a dataset
    ğŸ”—
    â€¢ They use phrases like â€œThis suggests...â€ or â€œIt appears that...â€
    ğŸ”—
    â€¢ Students ask permission before sharing information about classmates
    ğŸ”—
    Creation and Curation (Strand B):
    ğŸ”—
    â€¢ Students plan data collection before starting to gather information
    ğŸ”—
    â€¢ They notice and correct inconsistencies in how data is recorded
    ğŸ”—
    â€¢ Students organize data systematically for easier analysis
    ğŸ”—
    â€¢ They consider whether their sample represents the group they want to understand
    ğŸ”—
    Analysis and Modeling (Strand C):
    ğŸ”—
    â€¢ Students look for patterns beyond just finding the â€œbiggestâ€ or â€œsmallestâ€
    ğŸ”—
    â€¢ They explain variability rather than seeing it as a problem
    ğŸ”—
    â€¢ Students use data to make predictions and test them
    ğŸ”—
    â€¢ They choose appropriate tools for different types of analysis
    ğŸ”—
    Interpreting Problems and Results (Strand D):
    ğŸ”—
    â€¢ Students distinguish between correlation and causation
    ğŸ”—
    â€¢ They acknowledge limitations in their conclusions
    ğŸ”—
    â€¢ Students consider alternative explanations for what they observe
    ğŸ”—
    â€¢ They connect data findings back to real-world contexts
    ğŸ”—
    Visualization and Communication (Strand E):
    ğŸ”—
    â€¢ Students choose visualizations that match their data and audience
    ğŸ”—
    â€¢ They explain what their graphs show in their own words
    ğŸ”—
